Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, Chinese Academy of Forestry Nanjing 210042 China The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) strongly competes with electrocatalytic 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) oxidation, leading to low faradaic efficiency (FE), a narrow potential window, and reduced product yields. Herein, we demonstrate that a Ga-doped Co catalyst supported on nickel foam (Co-Ga/NF) effectively suppresses OER activity at ultralow potentials (1.25–1.40 V vs. RHE) while simultaneously promoting the HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR). Remarkably, the Co-Ga/NF system achieves > 95 % 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) yield with 97 % FE at 1.30 V vs. RHE. Structural characterization reveals that trace Ga doping induces abundant oxygen vacancies on the Co surface. Through combined in situ Raman spectroscopy and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), we elucidate that these surface defects facilitate reduced potential requirements for active site formation via hydroxyl adsorption (Co-OOH), thereby inhibiting OER while enhancing HMFOR activity and selectivity. These results provide a new strategy for regulating electrochemical upgrading of biomass. Graphical Abstract Keywords Low potential Electrocatalysis Integrated electrode Biomass oxidation Transition-metal Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Converting biomass-derived intermediates into high-value chemicals can significantly enhance biomass utilization [1]. 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has been identified by the U. S. Department of energy as one of the top 12 value added chemicals derived from biomass, owing to its crucial role as a precursor for the synthesis of polyamides, polyesters, and polyurethanes [2]. FDCA is typically produced by oxidizing 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) via stoichiometric, thermal, biological, photocatalytic, or electrocatalytic methods [3,4]. Among them, the electrocatalysis is gaining attention for its ability to convert HMF to FDCA under mild conditions [5–7]. The report on the HMF electrocatalytic oxidation to FDCA occurred in 1991 in a divided, H-shape cell in the presence of 1 M NaOH solution with Ni(OH)2/NiO(OH)-covered Ni mesh[8]. In the following decades, extensive research has been devoted to this field. Notably, noble-metal-based catalysts (such as Au [9,10], Pd [11], Ru [12], Ag [13], and Pt [14,15]) have demonstrated low onset potentials for HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR). However, owing to the high cost of noble metals, excessive base required, and undesirable catalytic activity for HMFOR, their widespread adoption remains limited. In contrast, non-noble metal catalytic systems have garnered increasing attention due to their diverse catalyst options, exceptional activities, and cost-effectiveness [16]. Among these, Co-based materials have been extensively studied for HMFOR, revealing that they demonstrate the lowest onset potential for HMF oxidation among non-noble metals [17,18]. However, the emergence of competitive oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at low potentials impedes the reaction rate of Co-based catalysts for HMFOR, resulting in reduced efficiency [16]. Efforts to construct electrocatalytic materials with reduced OER activity and improved HMFOR activity have been pursued through diverse synthetic strategies. For example, Suliman et al. achieved an HMFOR current density of 20 mA cm−2 at 1.37 V vs. RHE using CoB/g-C3N4 before the onset of the competing OER by manipulating the electronic structure of the Co center [19]. Chen et al. found that Cu-Ni bimetallic electrocatalytic impedes the deprotonation of OH* to O*, thereby significantly passivating the OER process due to Cu doping [20]. Nie et al. reported the fabrication of CoO doped with the transition metals. The incorporation of Cu reduced the charge transfer resistance of CoCuO x and enhanced the deintercalation capacity of OH−, thus optimizing the competitive adsorption between HMF and OH− [21]. Additionally, Wu et al. found that Ga doping can induce transient and radical transformations in the atomic and electronic structures of Sn and In during electrocatalytic processes, significantly influencing their catalytic performance. The Sn/In active components transitioned from phase-separated clusters to dispersed single atoms during the melting process, generating a unique electronic structure through the further reduction of metallic Sn/In and Ga [22]. Despite the development of various materials for electrocatalytic HMF oxidation, current catalytic systems are still hampered by low conversion efficiency and limited stability. In this work, we introduce a novel gallium-doped cobalt electrocatalyst Co-Ga/NF. By doping with Ga, the competitive oxygen evolution reaction is passivated. As a result, Co-Ga/NF achieves nearly complete conversion of HMF at low potential within ten cycles, with a Faradaic efficiency of 97 %. Structural characterization shows that gallium doping contributes to the disruption of the long-term cyclic order of lattice oxygen during cobalt oxide growth and generates oxygen vacancies, which facilitate OH* adsorption. This structure aids in selectively reducing the OER activity of Co. Electrochemical characterization indicates that Co-Ga/NF has a lower onset potential for HMFOR compared to most reported catalysts. In situ Raman and EIS analysis reveal that surface Ga doping plays a crucial role in reducing the onset potential for HMFOR. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and synthesis Nickel foam (NF) substrates (1 mm thickness) were cut into 1.0 cm × 2.0 cm pieces for further use. Specifically, nickel foam was first etched with 3 M HCl for 30 min to remove the surface oxides, followed by ultrasonication in ethanol for 30 min, respectively. The Nafion 117 membrane was immersed in 5 wt% H2O2, deionized water, 1.0 M H2SO4 and deionized water for 1 h at 60 °C. Preparation of Co-Ga/NF anode. Co-Ga/NF anode was fabricated by a facile electrodeposition method. The treated nickel foam was immersed in an aqueous solution containing 50 mM Co(NO3)2·6 H2O and X mM (X = 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 mM) Ga(NO3)3·9H2O. Electrodeposition process was conducted at 25 °C in a three-electrode system. Nickel foam served as the working electrode, platinum mesh as the counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode. The growth of the Co-Ga/NF pre-catalyst was achieved by applying a constant potential of −1.50 V vs. Ag/AgCl for 800 s (seen in Fig. 1(a)). The resulting nickel foam, loaded with nanosheets, was then thoroughly washed with deionized water and ethanol, followed by vacuum drying overnight. Subsequently, the prepared pre-catalyst was activated in a H-type electrolytic cell setup using cyclic voltammetry (CV) in 1 M KOH. The activation involved cycling the potential from 0.0 V to 1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl at a scan rate of 0.1 V/s for 20 cycles. Finally, the activated catalyst was immersed in 1 M KOH for 3 h to obtain the final catalyst, labeled as Co-Ga/NF (seen in Fig. 1(b)). Preparation of Co/NF anode. The Co/NF anode was prepared using a similar electrodeposition method. The treated nickel foam was immersed in an aqueous solution containing 50 mM Co(NO3)2·6 H2O for deposition. The Co/NF anode was then activated following the same steps used for the Co-Ga/NF catalyst, labeled as Co/NF. 2.2 Characterization A Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer with a scanning rate of 5 °·min−1 and a step size of 0.02° provided the XRD patterns of the samples. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (JEM-2100Plus) at 200 kV was used to examine the samples' nanoscale morphology while field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-7600F) was used to observe the samples' mesoscopic morphology at 30 kV. The chemical valent states of Co, O and Ga species were measured by an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, AXIS UltraDLD) with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray beam. All binding energies of elements were referenced to the C1s peak (284.6 eV). Oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was performed in an Auto Chem II 2920 device (Micromeritics). Typically, 100 mg of catalyst was pre-reduced at 200 °C for 1.0 h, and then the catalyst was cooled to room temperature in a He flow. Adsorption was carried out at 10 % O2/He flow for 0.5 h, and then the temperature was increased from 50 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. O-EPR tests were performed on a paramagnetic resonance spectrometer model Bruker EMXplus. Measurements of oxygen vacancies were performed at room temperature in the absence of light. In situ Raman spectroscopy was performed using a Thermo Scientific™ DXR spectrometer coupled with a CHI 760e electrochemical workstation to control the applied potentials. All spectra were acquired at room temperature using a custom-designed spectroelectrochemical quartz cell. Prior to measurements, the system was calibrated with a silicon wafer (reference peak at 520 cm−1). A semiconductor laser with a wavelength of 780 nm served as the excitation source, and a 50 × long-focus objective lens was employed to ensure vertical incidence onto the working electrode surface. Spectra were collected after holding the electrode at each target potential for 10 min to stabilize the interfacial environment. 2.3 Electrochemical performance measurements All the electrochemical measurements were performed by assembling a three-electrode system in an H-type cell, which was separated into a cathode cell and an anode cell by a membrane, at room temperature in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte with or without 10 mM HMF. The as-prepared catalysts, platinum network, and Ag/AgCl electrode were used as the working electrode, counter electrode, and reference electrode, respectively. All measured potentials used for electrochemical measurements in this study have been reported versusthe reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) and were converted using the equation: (1) E RHE = E Ag / AgCl + 0.059 × pH + 0.197 Under linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with a scan rate of 10 mV·s−1, 40 mL of 1.0 M KOH solution containing 10 mM HMF and without HMF were analyzed. In situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed in the range of 1.15–1.55 V and at frequencies from 105 to 10−2 Hz. The EIS data were fitted to the Randles circuit model R(QR) using Zview software to obtain optimal fitting parameters. These parameters included the solution resistance (Rs), double layer capacitance (Cdl), and charge transfer resistance (Rt). The current density normalized by the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was calculated using Eq. (2). (2) j ECSA = i / S ECSA where jECSA is the current density normalized by ECSA (mA cm−2); i is the current (mA); and SECSA is calculated as Cdl/Cs (with Cdl being the double layer capacitance and Cs=0.040 mF cm−2). 2.4 Products analysis The electrolyte was diluted 50 times with 980 μL of deionized water and analyzed using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) on an Agilent Technologies 1260 Infinity system. This system is equipped with a UV-Vis detector set at 265 nm and a 4.6 mm × 150 mm, 5 μm C18 column. Isocratic elution was performed with a solvent mixture of 70 % ammonium formate and 30 % methanol (run time: 10 min; flow rate: 0.6 mL/min; injection volume: 10 µL). The HMF conversion rate, yield, and Faradaic efficiency of the products were calculated using Eqs. (3), (4), and (5), respectively. The Faradaic efficiency of O2 was determined using Eq. (5). (3) Conversion ( % ) = [ n ( HMF consumed ) / n ( HMF initial ) ] × 100 (4) Yield ( % ) = [ n ( product ) / n ( HMF initial ) ] × 100 (5) Faradaic efficiency ( % ) = [ n ( FDCA formed ) / ( Charge / ( 6 × F ) ) ] × 100 The Faraday constant (F) is 96485 C·mol−1, and n represents the number of moles of reactants. Theoretically, assuming the transfer of 6 electrons during the oxidation process, the total charge for the oxidation of 10 mM HMF in 40 mL to FDCA is approximately 28 C, calculated as: (6) Total charge = 10 × 10−3 M × 40mL × 6 × 96485C·mol−3 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Electrochemical performance Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF were prepared by growing metals on nickel foam (NF) using a simple electrodeposition method (details shown in Fig. 1). Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were applied to investigate the anodic reactions, comparing the electrode performance of Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF in 1.0 M KOH solution with and without 10 mM HMF, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2(a), Co-Ga/NF exhibited a lower onset potential of ∼1.02 V (vs. RHE) for the HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR, solid line), while the onset potential for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) reached ∼1.20 V (dashed line). The potential required to achieve 20 mA cm−2 (Ej 2=20 mA cm−2), commonly referred to as the effective reaction current in literature [23], was reduced by ∼220 mV for HMFOR compared to OER, reaching 20 mA cm−2 at ∼1.20 V. In contrast, Co/NF showed relatively poor HMF oxidation activity due to its inherent high OER activity. The LSV curves of HMFOR and OER nearly overlapped in the range of 0.80–1.50 V (gray solid and dashed lines), indicating severe competitive reactions. Notably, Co-Ga/NF required lower potentials within the 20–60 mA cm−2 current range compared to most previously reported Co-based catalysts (Fig. 2(b) and Table 1), promoting rapid FDCA generation at low potentials and thereby reducing energy consumption. The kinetic behavior of the HMFOR reaction was investigated by analyzing the electron transfer rate derived from the Tafel slope (Fig. 2 c). For Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF, the OER Tafel slopes were 178.85 and 103.92 mV dec−1, respectively, suggesting that the Volmer step serves as the rate-determining step (RDS) for both catalysts. Notably, the introduction of HMF significantly reduced the Tafel slope of Co-Ga/NF to 33.68 mV dec−1, demonstrating its superior HMFOR kinetics compared to HER. In contrast, Co/NF exhibited only a marginal decrease in the Tafel slope (103.92→102.94 mV dec−1) upon HMF addition, implying potential competition between the two reactions. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF was evaluated using the double-layer capacitance (Cdl) method. Cyclic voltammetry was first performed for both catalysts in 1.0 M KOH with 50 mM HMF at varying scan rates (Fig. S1). The resulting currents were normalized to ECSA-based current density. As depicted in Fig. 2 d, Co-Ga/NF exhibited a higher intrinsic HMFOR activity (53.23 mF cm−2) than Co/NF (11.09 mF cm−2), further highlighting the critical role of Ga doping in enhancing HMFOR performance. The electrocatalytic activity for HMFOR was further evaluated. As illustrated in Fig. 3 a, HMF oxidation can proceed via two primary pathways: (I) conversion to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) or (II) oxidation to 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA). Both intermediates can subsequently be oxidized to 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) and ultimately to FDCA[32]. Chronoamperometry experiments at fixed potentials revealed distinct catalytic behaviors between the materials. Product distribution analysis at 1.30 V (Fig. 3b and c) demonstrated that both Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF exclusively produced HMFCA, FFCA and FDCA without DFF detection, confirming pathway II dominance. Remarkably, Co-Ga/NF achieved complete HMF conversion (100 %) with 270 C charge accumulation while maintaining exceptional FDCA selectivity (97.3 %), whereas Co/NF showed limited conversion (68.2 %) with substantial byproduct formation. The potential-dependent performance evaluation (Fig. 3d and e) highlighted Co-Ga/NF's superior catalytic efficiency, exhibiting > 80 % FDCA yields and Faradaic efficiencies across 1.25–1.40 V, peaking at 97.3 % and 95.8 % respectively at 1.30 V. In stark contrast, Co/NF consistently underperformed with yields and efficiencies below 50 % below 1.40 V, indicating significant OER competition impairing HMFOR efficiency. Co-Ga/NF's broader operational potential window enables energy-efficient FDCA production at lower voltages, offering practical advantages for cost-effective manufacturing. Repeated cycling tests (Fig. 3f) further validated the catalyst's robustness, showing stable FDCA production with maintained conversion and selectivity over ten consecutive runs, confirming excellent long-term stability. 3.2 Material characterizations XRD patterns of NF, Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF are shown in Fig. 4(a). There are three obvious diffraction peaks at 2θ = 44.51°, 51.85° and 76.37°, which are assigned to the characteristic peaks of nickel (JCPDS card No.87–0712). This indicates that electrodeposition treatment does not affect the crystal structure of the support. Moreover, the diffraction peaks of Co(OH)2 (JCPDS card No. 51–1731) and CoO (JCPDS card No. 42–1300) are shown to be present on both Co/NF and Co-Ga/NF in the detail map (Fig. 4(b)), whereas gallium is mainly appeared on Co-Ga/NF from the morphology of Ga2O3 (JCPDS card No. 41–1103). Observing the microstructural information of various catalysts from Fig. 5(a1, a2) and Fig. 5(b1, b2), it was found that the metal particles on the NF surface were evenly distributed and did not block the pores. For Co/NF anode, the metal particles exhibited a clear hexagonal nanosheet structure with a thickness of about 8 nm and were tightly adhered to the nickel foam substrate. In contrast, the metal particles on Ga/NF did not show a regular shape under SEM, indicating that the incorporation of Ga altered the growth structure of Co metal. Further, as observed in the low-resolution TEM images (Fig. 5(a3) and Fig. 5(b3)), the metal particles on the Co-Ga/NF also formed nanosheets, but with a much smaller size, measuring around 10 nm at their widest points. By comparison, the metal particles on Co/NF exceed 100 nm in size. The corresponding high-resolution TEM images (as seen in Fig. 5(a4) and Fig. 5(b4)) showed that, the lattice fringe spacing of the metal nanosheets on both catalysts was 0.254 nm, consistent with the (110) plane of β-Co(OH)₂. TEM-mapping element analysis (Fig. 5(c)) revealed that Ga, Co, and O elements were uniformly distributed within the nanosheets of Co-Ga/NF. And on the surface of Co/NF, Co and O elements were also uniformly distributed (Fig. S3). Accordingly, the method of electrodeposition facilitated the uniform dispersion of the catalyst. The statistics of the elemental mapping results (Table S1) revealed that the O elemental content on the Co-Ga/NF surface (41 %) was higher than that of Co/NF (31 %). Meanwhile, the Ga elemental content on Co-Ga/NF was only 2 %, which was much lower than the Co elemental content (52 %). This finding suggests that there is a loss of Ga during catalyst preparation, which may be the main reason why the lattice of Ga was not noticed from high-resolution TEM images. We analyzed the O1 s, Co2p, and Ga2p X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF to examine structural and valence changes after Ga doping. The O1 s spectra ( Fig. 6a) show three deconvoluted peaks at 528.7, 530.3, and 531.5 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (OⅠ), surface oxygen species (OⅠⅠ), and oxygen of surface hydroxyl (-OH), respectively [33]. Quantitative analysis ( Table 2) reveals that Co-Ga/NF contains significantly more lattice oxygen and surface oxygen species than Co/NF, particularly surface oxygen species (61.33 %: 51.94 %). This indicates increased oxygen defects in Co after Ga doping. In order to further verify the morphological changes of cobalt, the XPS (Fig. 6(b)) of Co2p region presents two asymmetric main peaks at 775–785 and 793–800 eV, which correspond to Co2p 3/2 region and Co2p 1/2 region. The deconvolution for samples by Gaussian peak fitting indicates the presence of Co2+ and Co+ species [34]. As displayed in Table 2, the percentage of Co2+ and Co+ species in Co-Ga/NF is 89.67 % and 10.33 %, respectively. In comparison, Co/NF has 46.40 % and 53.60 % of Co2+ and Co+ species, respectively.The Co binding energy of Co-Ga/NF is shifted to higher wavelengths, indicating partial electron loss of Co. In the Ga2p spectrum of Co-Ga/NF (Fig. 6 c), the main peak at 1117.53 eV corresponds to Ga3+ [35]. Interestingly, Ga3d XPS (Fig. S4) shows slightly reduced Ga³ ⁺ content compared to the pre-oxidation state. Combined with TEM observations of low Ga content, this suggests partial Ga removal during pre-oxidation. As is well known, ion doping can easily generate vacancies because doping agents can disrupt the long-term periodic order of lattice oxygen in oxides. For example, when low-priced M3+ dopants are added to MO2, the low-priced M3+ will replace the original metal nodes in MO2 and generate oxygen vacancies to maintain electrostatic balance [36].Correspondingly, in Co-Ga/NF, the enhanced surface oxygen species signal and Co2p positive binding energy shift suggest that Ga3+ doping introduces oxygen-deficient sites on Co2+ surfaces. These sites may adsorb oxygen-containing species, potentially enhancing HMFOR activity. As shown in Fig. 7(a), oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was employed to investigate the oxygen adsorption capacity of different catalysts. Both Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF exhibited two characteristic peaks, corresponding to physiosorbed oxygen at 77 °C and chemisorbed oxygen at 263 °C[37]. Peak intensity comparison revealed comparable physiosorption capabilities between the two catalysts, while Co-Ga/NF demonstrated significantly enhanced chemisorption capacity. Oxygen vacancy concentrations were further quantified by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analysis (Fig. 7(b)). Co-Ga/NF exhibited enhanced EPR signal intensity compared to Co/NF (g-factor = 2.003), indicating higher oxygen vacancy density. This mechanistic evidence confirms that Ga incorporation induces structural defects, generating abundant oxygen vacancies that facilitate chemisorbed oxygen activation—a critical factor for improved catalytic performance in FDCA synthesis. 3.3 Mechanism analysis In situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out in the range of 1.15–1.55 V to deeply investigate the electrochemical oxidation behavior of Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF. As the applied potential is raised, the nyquist plot of Co-Ga/NF for HMFOR gradually collapsed from a large semicircle at 1.15 V to a small semicircle at 1.50 V ( Fig. 8(a)), indicating the enhancement of the Faraday reaction (HMFOR) and the weakening of the non-Faraday reaction[38,39]. The EIS of Co-Ga/NF for OER showed that the steep line of the Nyquist plot gradually increased in slope with increasing potential at 1.15 V, indicating that the Faraday reaction (OER) did not occur (Fig. 8(b)). The slope was maximized when the potential reached 1.45 V. As the potential continued to increase until the potential reached 1.55 V, the steep line refolded into a semicircle, indicating that OER occurs in this interval (1.45–1.55 V). In addition, the nyquist plot of Co/NF for HMFOR (Fig. 8(c)) showed steep line folding from 1.20 V to 1.50 V, proving the existence of HMFOR. However, the folding had occurred at a very low efficiency, and the inability to form a distinct semicircle meant that the reaction proceeded very slowly, which made Faraday less efficient. The EIS of Co/NF for OER (Fig. 8d) showed a gradual decrease in the slope of the steep line of impedance starting from 1.15 V until 1.55 V, proving the continuous occurrence of OER. The collected Nyquist plots of Co/NF for both HMFOR and OER showed the simultaneous presence of Faraday reaction, which indicated that Co/NF without gallium-doped was difficult to reduce the charge transfer resistance to avoid competition from OER. The bode phase diagrams of Co-Ga/NF for HMFOR and OER (Fig. 8(e, f)) both showed prominent peaks centered at low frequencies, and the peaks at low frequencies (<100 Hz) were related to the Volmer step, which represented the interfacial reaction charge transfer[40]. While the peaks located in the mid-frequency region (100 ∼ 102 Hz) were associated with relatively slow Heyrovsky steps and usually represented surface oxidation interface[41]. As a result of the pre-oxidation treatment, the Co-Ga/NF did not show a mid- to high-frequency interference peak at this position. When the voltage is increased from 1.15 V to 1.45 V, the phase angle of the outgoing peaks of the Co-Ga/NF for HMFOR gradually becomes smaller. The LSV analysis showed that the HMFOR occurs at the low-frequency interface between Co-Ga/NF and the electric double layer (Fig. 2(a)). Subsequently, an increase in phase angle was observed at 1.50 V, indicating the emergence of a new high-resistance interface (Fig. 8(e)). Decreased phase angle and outgoing peaks were again observed at 1.55 V, showing that OER started to occur during this period. In contrast to HMFOR, the Co-Ga/NF corresponding to OER does not show a transition peak until after the voltage reaches 1.55 V vs (Fig. 8(f)). We therefore infer that the oxygen species generated by Co-Ga/NF in the range of 1.15–1.45 V is almost exclusively used for HMFOR rather than OER depletion due to the severe OER suppression. To investigate the differences in the dynamic structural evolution of Co-Ga/NF and Co/NF during HMFOR and to elucidate the role of oxygen vacancies on Co-Ga/NF during the reaction, In situ Raman spectroscopy was conducted. As shown in Fig. 9, under open-circuit conditions (black curves), CoGa/NF exhibits an additional broad peak centered at ∼600 cm−1 compared to Co/NF, which is attributed to the characteristic Co-O bond vibration (B2 g mode)[42]. This indicates the presence of defect sites on Co-Ga/NF, which facilitate oxygen adsorption, consistent with the EPR results. As shown in Fig. 9a, with increasing applied potential, the Co-O vibrational mode gradually diminishes, and two new prominent peaks (463 and 585 cm−1) emerge between 1.1 and 1.5 V. These peaks can be attributed to the δ(CoIII-O) (in-plane vibration along the a-b axis, Eg mode, O-Co-O bending) and ν(CoIII-O) (axial vibration along the c-axis, A1 g mode, O-Co-O stretching) vibrations of CoOOH, respectively [42,43]. The formation of these peaks suggests the transformation of Co species into CoOOH under operational conditions.。In contrast, the characteristic peaks of CoOOH emerge on Co/NF only when the potential reaches 1.4 V (Fig. 9b). In both systems, the potentials corresponding to the appearance of CoOOH characteristic peaks align closely with the potentials observed in LSVs and EIS measurements. These findings demonstrate that the catalytically active species for the electrochemical HMFOR is CoOOH. The oxygen-deficient sites on the Co-Ga/NF surface facilitate the formation of CoOOH at lower potentials, thereby accelerating the reaction kinetics and modulating the overall catalytic pathway. 3.4 Discussion As mentioned above, it can be confirmed that Ga doping can significantly improve the activity of the catalyst for HMF oxidation under low potential conditions. The XRD, SEM, and TEM results (Figs. 4 and 5) showed that gallium doping does not change the morphology of the matrix nickel foam, but disrupts the long-term periodic order of lattice oxygen during cobalt oxide growth. Specifically, Co-Ga/NF has a crystalline phase of Co similar to that of Co/NF, but forms smaller and thinner crystalline particle sizes. Many studies have shown that the size and thickness of the lamellar active sites influence the good contact of the catalyst with the reactants [44]. The continuity of the reaction is favored by gallium doping. Based on comprehensive characterization through XPS, O2-TPD, and O-EPR analyses (Figs. 6 and 7), Co-Ga/NF demonstrates a higher concentration of defect sites capable of adsorbing surface oxygen species compared to Co/NF. This phenomenon can be attributed to the inherent nature of ion doping, which readily generates oxygen vacancies by disrupting the long-range periodic order of lattice oxygen in the oxide matrix. Specifically, the introduction of trivalent Ga ions promotes the formation of defect sites through electronic interactions with divalent Co during the doping process. The enhanced oxygen vacancy concentration likely serves as the primary factor responsible for the distinct electrocatalytic oxidation activity of HMF observed on Co-Ga/NF compared to the undoped Co/NF catalyst. The in situ EIS results further elucidate the critical role of oxygen defects in the electrochemical processes. Within the potential range of 1.15–1.45 V, Co-Ga/NF exhibits exclusive dominance of HMFOR over OER, which can be attributed to the efficient trapping of free OH* intermediates by oxygen vacancies. This suppression prevents their further conversion into O* species, thereby inhibiting the OER pathway. Surface doping with metals can trigger a negative electric field, which limits OH- affinity through electrostatic repulsion but promotes HMF adsorption, thereby leading to OER deterioration and e-HMFOR enhancement [45,46]. In situ electrochemical Raman spectroscopy provides additional validation, confirming CoOOH as the catalytically active species for HMFOR. Notably, the oxygen-deficient sites on the Co-Ga/NF surface facilitate the formation of CoOOH at lower potentials, significantly enhancing the reaction kinetics under low-potential conditions. Based on the above results and discussions, we propose a comprehensive reaction mechanism for HMFOR on Co-Ga/NF ( Fig. 10). The Co-Ga/NF surface, enriched with oxygen species near Ga sites, facilitates the low-potential ionization of water to generate OH* intermediates. These OH* species rapidly accumulate, forming Co-O-OH active sites. During HMFOR, HMF preferentially adsorbs onto lattice oxygen sites [47], ensuring that competitive adsorption between OH* and HMF* is minimized. This allows both species to participate efficiently in the oxidation and dehydrogenation steps. The reaction proceeds via a two-step mechanism. Step Ⅰ: HMF* reacts with OH* to form HMFCA, which subsequently undergoes dehydrogenation to yield FFCA. Step Ⅱ: FFCA* further reacts with OH* to produce the final product, FDCA [48]. The oxygen-deficient structure of Co-Ga/NF plays a critical role in this process by promoting the rapid formation of Co-O-OH at low potentials. This not only accelerates the two-step oxidation of HMF but also enhances the overall electrocatalytic performance under mild conditions. 4 Conclusion In this study, gallium-doped cobalt electrocatalysts (Co-Ga/NF) were synthesized via electrodeposition, exhibiting significantly enhanced HMF electrooxidation (HMFOR) activity and expanded operational potential windows. The onset potential of Co-Ga/NF was lower than most reported Co-based electrodes. Structural characterization indicates that, Ga doping disrupts the lattice oxygen cycling during cobalt oxide growth, inducing defect formation. In situ Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that adsorbed oxygen species at these defects promote preferential OH* adsorption under anodic bias, generating catalytically active Co-O-OH species. Operando electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) further validated that these OH* intermediates critically modulate HMFOR pathways by suppressing O* formation and passivating the competing oxygen evolution reaction (OER). coredata.dc:description: The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) strongly competes with electrocatalytic 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) oxidation, leading to low faradaic efficiency (FE), a narrow potential window, and reduced product yields. Herein, we demonstrate that a Ga-doped Co catalyst supported on nickel foam (Co-Ga/NF) effectively suppresses OER activity at ultralow potentials (1.25–1.40 V vs. RHE) while simultaneously promoting the HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR). Remarkably, the Co-Ga/NF system achieves > 95 % 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) yield with 97 % FE at 1.30 V vs. RHE. Structural characterization reveals that trace Ga doping induces abundant oxygen vacancies on the Co surface. Through combined in situ Raman spectroscopy and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), we elucidate that these surface defects facilitate reduced potential requirements for active site formation via hydroxyl adsorption (Co-OOH), thereby inhibiting OER while enhancing HMFOR activity and selectivity. These results provide a new strategy for regulating electrochemical upgrading of biomass.
coredata.dc:title: Trace gallium doping in cobalt-based anode catalysts enables low-potential electrooxidation of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural
